clinical_study.brief_title: Micro-interventions Aiming to Optimize Expectations or Self-compassion to Improve Well-being/Reduce Stress and Their Differential Effects
clinical_study.official_title: Micro-interventions Aiming to Optimize Expectations or Self-compassiong and Their Differential Effects

brief_summary.textblock: The study's aim is to determine whether brief interventions (micro-interventions) aiming to optimize expectations or enhancing feelings of self-compassion are able to improve well-being/reduce perceived stress in comparison to an active control group in an online-study

detailed_description.textblock: In this study we use a pre-post-test design to compare the effects of the (classic) best possible self intervention vs. the best possible self intervention (including ways on how to reach the imagined best possible future) vs. a self-compassion intervention vs. an active control group. We are interested in the differential effects and examine several moderators.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from pre (baseline) to post scores (approx. 30 minutes later)
primary_outcome.description: Participants are asked to rate how stressed they feel at the moment at two time points (baseline and the intervention) on a questionnaire (VAS: item ranges from 0 (not stressed at all) - 100 (very stressed). Change scores are calculated (post- minus pre-scores; pre-scores will be used as a covariate). e.g.Lesage, F.-X., Berjot, S., & Deschamps, F. (2012). Clinical stress assessment using a visual ana-logue scale. Occupational Medicine, 62(8), 600-605. https://doi.org/10.1093/occmed/kqs140

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in perceived (stress) burden ratings (resulting from perceived stress)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from pre (baseline) to post scores (approx. 30 minutes later)
secondary_outcome.description: Participants are asked to rate how burdened they feel at the moment at two time points (baseline and the intervention) due to the experienced stress on a questionnaire (VAS: item ranges from 0 (not at all) - 100 (very much). Change scores are calculated (post- minus pre-scores; pre-scores will be used as a covariate). Indirect/opposite measure of well-being.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from pre (baseline) to post scores (approx. 30 minutes later)
secondary_outcome.description: Change scores are calculated for positive and negative sum scores (post- minus pre-scores; pre-scores will be used as a covariate). Krohne, H.W., Egloff, B., Kohlmann, C.W., & Tausch, A. (1996). Experiments with a German version of the "Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (PANAS). Diagnostica, 42, 139-156.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from pre (baseline) to post scores (approx. 30 minutes later)
secondary_outcome.description: State Optimism measure (SOM), 7 items (each item 1(strongly disagree)-5(strongly agree)). Change scores are calculated for positive and negative sum scores (post- minus pre-scores; pre-scores will be used as a covariate). Millstein, R. A., Chung, W. J., Hoeppner, B. B., Boehm, J. K., Legler, S. R., Mastromauro, C. A., & Huffman, J. C. (2019). Development of the State Optimism Measure. General hospital psychiatry, 58, 83-93

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from pre (baseline) to post scores (approx. 30 minutes later)
secondary_outcome.description: Change in state self-compassion (SCS-state), 16 items (each item 1(strongly disagree) - 5 (strongly agree)). Change scores are calculated (post- minus pre-scores; pre-scores will be used as a covariate). Breines, J. G., & Chen, S. (2013). Activating the inner caregiver: The role of support-giving schemas in increasing state self-compassion. Journal of Experimental Social Psychology, 49(1), 58-64. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jesp.2012.07.015

secondary_outcome.measure: Satisfaction ratings with the respective intervention
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Only Post-Assessment (end of the experiment; approx. 45-60 minutes after start of the experiment)
secondary_outcome.description: e.g. "I was satisfied with the intervention" or "I feel like I had a benefit from this intervention"

secondary_outcome.measure: Ratings directly assessing the perceived change due to the intervention
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Only Post-Assessment (end of the experiment; approx. 45-60 minutes after start of the experiment)
secondary_outcome.description: e.g. "The intervention reduced my perceived stress", "The intervention increased my feeling of being able to influence things"

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from pre (baseline) to post scores (approx. 30 minutes later)
secondary_outcome.description: Change in perceived self-efficacy (SWE), 10 items (each item (1(not at all) - 4(exactly)). Change scores are calculated (post- minus pre-scores; pre-scores will be used as a covariate). SchwarzerR& Jerusalem M. Generalized Self--‐Efficacy scale. In J. Weinman, S. Wright, &M. Johnston, Measures in health psychology: A user's portfolio. Causal andcontrol beliefs (pp. 35--‐37). 1995. Windsor, England: NFER--‐NELSON.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in anxiety and depression state (STADI)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from pre (baseline) to post scores (approx. 30 minutes later)
secondary_outcome.description: Change in anxiety and depression state (STADI), 20 items (each item 1(strongly disagree) - 4 (strongly agree)). Change scores are calculated (post- minus pre-scores; pre-scores will be used as a covariate). Laux, L., Hock, M., Bergner-Köther, R., Hodapp, V., & Renner, K. H. (2013). The State-Trait-Anxiety-Depression-Inventory-Manual. Göttingen, Germany: Hogrefe.

clinical_study.condition: no Specific Clincal Condition Required (Focus is on Persons Who Are Feeling Stressed or Want to Improve Their Wellbeing)

arm_group.description: Participants are asked to think and write about their best possible future self and to imagine this positive future subsequently.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Experimental group 2: Best Possible Self + next steps
arm_group.description: Participants are asked to think and write about their best possible future self and what the next steps could be to reach that best possible future. Subsequently, participants are asked to imagine this positive future.
Participants are asked to think and write about a self-compassion exercise and to imagine this content subsequently.
Participants are asked to think and write about a neutral task that is comparable to the experimental groups.

intervention.description: All participants are asked to take some time to think and write about the content of the respective intervention group. After the writing exercise (approx. 15-20 min) participants are asked to imagine that content for about 5 minutes.
intervention.arm_group_label: Experimental group 2: Best Possible Self + next steps

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- fluent in German language
- access to a computer/tablet/smartphone with audio output/headphones
Exclusion Criteria:
- not willing to take part in an online-intervention (duration: 60 minutes)
- no access to a computer/tablet/smartphone with audio output/headphones
